news_summary: A significant 54 million euro grant was signed in Tirana to enhance transport development in the Western Balkans, boosting regional connectivity and infrastructure.
news_summary_fr: Une importante subvention de 54 millions d'euros a été signée à Tirana pour renforcer le développement des transports dans les Balkans occidentaux, en stimulant la connectivité et l'infrastructure régionales.
news_summary_es: En Tirana se firmó una importante subvención de 54 millones de euros para potenciar el desarrollo del transporte en los Balcanes Occidentales, impulsando la conectividad y las infraestructuras regionales.

articles.title: BE-BB signs in Tirana a grant of 54 million euros for the development of transport in the Western Balkans
articles.summary: The Director for the Western Balkans in the Directorate-General for Enlargement and Neighbourhood Policy at the European Commission, Valentina Superti, emphasized that the fund of 54 million euros will contribute to improving road and rail safety, increasing technical capacities, digitizing systems, and expanding lanes.
articles.content:
The Director for the Western Balkans in the Directorate-General for Enlargement and Neighbourhood Policy at the European Commission, Valentina Superti, emphasized that the fund of 54 million euros will contribute to improving road and rail safety, increasing technical capacities, digitizing systems, and expanding lanes.

The signing ceremony of the grant agreement provided by the World Bank and the European Union for the safe and sustainable transport program, administered by the WB, took place in Tirana.

The grant was signed within the framework of the summit “Growth Plan – Our Path to the EU,” held in the Albanian capital.

At the ceremony, Valentina Superti, the director for the Western Balkans at the Directorate-General for Enlargement and Neighbourhood Policy at the European Commission, emphasized that the fund of 54 million euros will contribute to improving road and rail safety, increasing technical capacities, digitizing systems, and expanding lanes.

This grant adds to previous funding, bringing the total EU support to 134 million euros since 2023.

“This fund demonstrates the importance that the European Union attaches to this program and will facilitate traffic at border points, promoting regional trade,” said the representative of the European Commission.

Xiaoqing Yu, the World Bank director for the Western Balkans, expressed optimism for cooperation with the EU and emphasized that this new grant is a sign of commitment to the development of transport in the Western Balkans.

According to her, this is just the first initiative, while other projects are planned for improving infrastructure and regional transport capacities.

The Transport Facilitation Program 2 is a concrete example of support for the region and its integration into the EU, aiming for a safer, digital, and more efficient transport network for the entire Western Balkans.

The summit “Growth Plan – Our Path to the EU,” held in Tirana, brought together leaders from the Western Balkans and high-ranking officials from the European Union. Discussions were held at the summit on ways to accelerate the implementation of the EU Growth Plan and how this process can turn into a success story for the citizens of the Western Balkans. (November 25)

articles.personality_title: EU and World Bank provide 54 million euros to improve transport in Western Balkans
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Western Balkans region is working to improve its transport systems, which include roads and railways, to make travel safer and more efficient. The European Union (EU) and the World Bank have been supporting these efforts with funding.

**What happened** – On November 25, in Tirana, Albania, a grant agreement worth 54 million euros was signed. This money comes from the EU and the World Bank to support a program that focuses on safer and more modern transport in the Western Balkans. The program will improve road and rail safety, increase technical skills, add digital systems, and expand traffic lanes.

**Impact** – This grant is part of a larger effort, adding to previous funds to reach a total of 134 million euros since 2023. It will help make transport across borders smoother, which can boost trade between countries in the region. The improvements will also make traveling safer for people and help connect the Western Balkans more closely with the European Union.

**What’s next step** – The Transport Facilitation Program 2 is just the beginning. More projects are planned to continue improving roads, railways, and transport technology in the region. Leaders from the Western Balkans and the EU will keep working together to speed up these changes and support the region’s growth.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new 54 million euro grant from the EU and World Bank will make transport in the Western Balkans safer, faster, and more connected to Europe.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE et la Banque mondiale accordent 54 millions d'euros pour améliorer les transports dans les Balkans occidentaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La région des Balkans occidentaux cherche à améliorer ses systèmes de transport, notamment les routes et les chemins de fer, pour rendre les déplacements plus sûrs et plus efficaces. L'Union européenne (UE) et la Banque mondiale soutiennent ces efforts par des financements.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 25 novembre à Tirana, en Albanie, un accord de subvention de 54 millions d'euros a été signé. Cette somme provient de l'UE et de la Banque mondiale pour un programme visant à rendre les transports dans les Balkans occidentaux plus sûrs et modernes. Ce programme améliorera la sécurité routière et ferroviaire, augmentera les compétences techniques, ajoutera des systèmes numériques et élargira les voies de circulation.

**Impact** – Cette subvention s'inscrit dans un effort plus large, portant le total à 134 millions d'euros depuis 2023. Elle facilitera les transports aux frontières, ce qui peut stimuler le commerce entre les pays de la région. Ces améliorations rendront aussi les déplacements plus sûrs pour les personnes et renforceront la connexion des Balkans occidentaux avec l'Union européenne.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Programme de facilitation des transports 2 n'est que le début. D'autres projets sont prévus pour continuer à améliorer les routes, les chemins de fer et la technologie des transports. Les dirigeants des Balkans occidentaux et de l'UE continueront de collaborer pour accélérer ces changements et soutenir la croissance de la région.

**Phrase clé** – Une nouvelle subvention de 54 millions d'euros de l'UE et de la Banque mondiale rendra les transports dans les Balkans occidentaux plus sûrs, plus rapides et mieux connectés à l'Europe.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE y el Banco Mundial otorgan 54 millones de euros para mejorar el transporte en los Balcanes Occidentales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La región de los Balcanes Occidentales está trabajando para mejorar sus sistemas de transporte, como carreteras y ferrocarriles, para hacer los viajes más seguros y eficientes. La Unión Europea (UE) y el Banco Mundial han apoyado estos esfuerzos con financiamiento.

**Qué pasó** – El 25 de noviembre, en Tirana, Albania, se firmó un acuerdo de subvención de 54 millones de euros. Este dinero proviene de la UE y el Banco Mundial para apoyar un programa que busca un transporte más seguro y moderno en los Balcanes Occidentales. El programa mejorará la seguridad vial y ferroviaria, aumentará las capacidades técnicas, añadirá sistemas digitales y ampliará los carriles.

**Impacto** – Esta subvención es parte de un esfuerzo mayor, sumando fondos que alcanzan un total de 134 millones de euros desde 2023. Ayudará a facilitar el transporte en las fronteras, lo que puede impulsar el comercio entre países de la región. Las mejoras también harán que viajar sea más seguro y conectarán mejor los Balcanes Occidentales con la Unión Europea.

**Próximo paso** – El Programa de Facilitación del Transporte 2 es solo el comienzo. Se planean más proyectos para continuar mejorando las carreteras, ferrocarriles y tecnología de transporte en la región. Los líderes de los Balcanes Occidentales y la UE seguirán trabajando juntos para acelerar estos cambios y apoyar el crecimiento regional.

**Frase clave** – Una nueva subvención de 54 millones de euros de la UE y el Banco Mundial hará que el transporte en los Balcanes Occidentales sea más seguro, rápido y mejor conectado con Europa.
